item.title: Ramaphosa won't be charged over farm scandal - SA prosecutor
item.description: South Africa's president faced questions after $4m in cash was stolen from a sofa on his farm.

item.title: Joe Biden "Courageous" To Step Out Of US Elections 2024: Kamala Harris
item.description: US Vice President Kamala Harris said that Joe Biden's decision to drop out of the 2024 election race this summer was "one of the most courageous" any president has made.

item.title: "Approach Should Be Of Development, Not Expansion": PM At East Asia Summit
item.description: Noting that conflicts in different parts of the world are having the most negative impact on the countries of the Global South, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday called for the restoration of peace and stability in Eurasia and West Asia.

item.title: Conflict Between Israel and Iran Adds to Oil Market Volatility
item.description: Israel and Iran are fighting at a time when prices are under pressure because of weak demand in China and concerns about oversupply.

item.title: How The Times Investigated Indian Political Ties to Labor Abuse in the Sugar Industry
item.description: Western companies such as Coca-Cola buy sugar from fields where workers suffer abuses. But the country has labor laws. Where was the government?

item.title: Why Lawmakers Ignore Human Rights Abuses in India’s Sugar Fields
item.description: Politicians run most of the mills in the state of Maharashtra. They deny or downplay evidence of coerced hysterectomies, debt bondage and child labor in the fields.

item.title: Middle East crisis live: call for UN inquiry after fresh Israeli attack on peacekeepers in Lebanon
item.description:
Human Rights Watch says urgent investigation needed after UN peacekeepers injured in third attack in three days

Israel’s Magen David Adom has reported that one person has been killed and another wounded at a kibbutz in northern Israel by anti-tank fire from Lebanon.

Israel’s emergency services said the person killed was a 27-year-old Thai national working at kibbutz Yiron.

Continue reading...

item.title: Tories would have to support ECHR withdrawal ‘to serve in my shadow cabinet’, says Jenrick – UK politics live
item.description:
Conservative leadership hopeful’s plan could lead to many senior Tories refusing to serve on the frontbench

The UK economy returned to growth in August after flatlining for two months, in a boost for the chancellor, Rachel Reeves, before the autumn budget, Richard Partington reports.

The main announcement from No 10 this morning is “thousands of jobs in green industries announced as the UK government welcomes more than £24bn of private investment for pioneering energy projects ahead of the International Investment Summit on 14 October”.

The government’s big announcement going into this morning was the news that private sector firms have poured £24 billion in new investment into green energy projects. This includes a £12 billion investment from Spanish firm Iberdrola and £8 billion from Denmark’s Ørsted.

Not so fast: However, Politico’s Senior UK energy correspondent Charlie Cooper texts in to say most of the money involved is not actually new. He points out that the Iberdrola and Ørsted investments were publicly announced more than a month ago and came through Britain’s contracts for difference scheme. Nice try, though!

Continue reading...

item.title: Robert Jenrick makes pitch to Tory centre with Cleverly frontbench offer
item.description:
Conservative leadership candidate says he would be ‘delighted’ for eliminated rival to join his shadow cabinet

The Conservative leadership hopeful Robert Jenrick has made a pitch to the centre of his party, saying he would be “delighted” for James Cleverly to join the shadow cabinet.

Cleverly, a centrist, was eliminated from the race on Wednesday, leaving the party with a choice between Kemi Badenoch and Jenrick, both on the populist right.

Continue reading...
